thread.title: Demetriou rules himself out of the running
thread.title_full: Demetriou rules himself out of the running

author: David Riccio and Neil Cordy
title: Demetriou rules himself out of the running
text:
Video Image Was Smith pushed? 9:16 NRL: Jimmy Smith joins Fox Sports News to discuss NRL CEO Dave Smith's resignation from his post.
October 20th 2015 6 hours ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/NRL/ Former AFL chief executive Andrew Demetriou says he doesn’t want to be NRL CEO. Picture: David Caird.
David Riccio and Neil Cordy The Daily Telegraph FORMER AFL chief executive Andrew Demetriou has ruled himself out of becoming the new boss of the NRL following CEO Dave Smith’s resignation on Tuesday.
ARL chairman John Grant confirmed the NRL will conduct a worldwide recruitment search — an exercise which could cost thousands of dollars — for Smith’s replacement as chief executive, despite a string of leading local candidates emerging immediately following Tuesday’s announcement.
No sooner had the curtain come down on Smith’s 34-minute final press conference that the names of NRL head of football Todd Greenberg, NRL head of strategy Shane Richardson, Gold Coast Titans CEO Graham Annesley, NSWRL CEO David Trodden and Penrith CEO Warren Wilson were mentioned along the corridors of League Central.
But it seems the one man NRL fans want, isn’t interested in the role.
After running the AFL for 11 seasons, Demetriou quit as CEO in 2014. He did so leaving a legacy of exponential growth under his leadership and ultimately transforming the AFL into the top footy code in Australia.
Todd Greenberg is being touted as possible replacement for Dave Smith. Source: News Corp Australia
A recent Sunday Telegraph poll indicated more than 65 per cent of fans wanted Demetriou to take over the NRL.
But after accepting several positions on company board’s, including James Packer’s Crown Resorts, Demetriou indicated his time under the spotlight, pressure and critique that is sport’s administration was over.
GONE: Smith quits as NRL CEO
REACTION: How fans and colleague reacted to Smith announcement
PODCAST: BUZZ ON DAVE SMITH’S DECISION TO WALK AWAY
“I’m having too much fun what I’m doing now,’’ Demetriou sent via an SMS text message to The Daily Telegraph.
Momentarily, Grant has been appointed the interim CEO until a replacement can be found.
“When you look at our executive team they are a good team who understand their job and are doing a great job,’’ Grant said.
“It would have been very disruptive to pull one of those out as we would have to backfill that person by moving someone else. We made the decision that’s its just too disruptive.’’
BUZZ: Eastern suburbs banker didn’t get NRL
REPLACEMENT: Who fills Smith’s shoes?
However, he could not guarantee the ARL Commission would announce a replacement to Smith before the 2016 kick-off in March.
“The objective is to get the right person in the job and that’s the process that we’ll go through,’’ Grant said.
Who should replace Dave Smith as NRL CEO? “Our job as a commission is to ensure we make sure we get that. So we’re working to that process and that’s what we’ll do.’’
In a strong indication that Greenberg — who was appointed by Smith in 2013 — and Richardson would be given every chance to apply for the role, Grant said: “One of Dave’s objectives of being CEO was to bring on people who could potentially be successors to him over the long-term.
“That was the plan.
“We’ve got a search now which starts straight away, its an internal and external search and we’re hopeful that internal candidates stick their hand up.
“We’ll get the right candidate. The end job of the commission to get the right person.’’
THE CONTENDERS
Todd Greenberg
NRL head of football
TAB mock odds: $7
Has made no secret of his desire to become CEO. Genuine frontrunner.
Graham Annesley
Gold Coast Titans CEO
TAB mock odds: $15
Back to the future. Knows the game and the power players. Brings knowledge and stability
Warren Wilson
Penrith Panthers CEO
TAB mock odds: $6
Versatile having worked previously with TAB and now leading administrator from clubland
Shane Richardson
NRL head of strategy
The former Rabbitohs boss’ current role allows him to already have one foot in the door.
Phil Gould
Penrith Panthers general manager
TAB mock odds: $81
Has declared time and again on social media he has no interest in running the game.
Andrew Demetriou
Former AFL CEO and fan favourite
TAB mock odds: $21
Loving life too much to dare step back into the hot seat.
Dave Trodden
NSWRL chief executive
TAB mock odds: $21
Smart operator. In touch with the game’s fabric and enjoys support from NSW club heavyweights.
Raelene Castle
Canterbury Bulldogs CEO
TAB mock odds: $15
Outstanding CEO who is media savvy and not afraid to make a tough call.
 Demetriou rules himself out of the running
